p: HIV self-testing also has the potential to overcome logistical barriers raised by men, such as distance from the clinic and time constraints. In other countries, a range of delivery methods for self-testing have been utilised, including online ordering,[ 68] purchasing from pharmacies [ 69], provision by women (both female sex workers and pregnant women) to male partners [ 70– 75], household delivery [ 76], and vending machines [ 77]. These studies indicate that the efficiency of provision and saving of time are key motivators to using self-testing [ 65, 68, 78– 80]. Fear of an invasive testing method also emerged as a reason for the men’s reluctance to get an HIV test. This issue can be resolved by HIV self-testing, especially modalities that make use of oral fluids [ 81]. A demonstration project using self-testing using oral fluids revealed a 6–7 times higher likelihood of testing uptake compared to conventional blood-based HIV testing at the clinic [ 82].
